aside.h4: What can I do to stop the spread of illness?
aside.p:
DCCS is closing for this extended period to help reduce the spread of COVID-19 in our community. We encourage our families to do what they can to limit their potential exposure.
Good hygiene practices are the best way to prevent the spread of any kind of illness:

ul.li: Wash your hands often with soap and water, for at least 20 seconds especially after you cough or sneeze. Alcohol-based hand cleaners are also effective.
Cover your nose and mouth with a tissue when you cough or sneeze. Throw the tissue in the trash after you use it.
Cough or sneeze into your sleeve, rather than your hands, if a tissue is not available.

Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects in your home, such as doorknobs, handles (cabinet knobs, fridge, oven, microwave) light switches, phones, iPads, keyboards, remote control, pet toys, counter tops, toilets, sinks/faucets, etc.
Try to avoid close contact with sick people.
If you get sick, stay home from work or school and limit contact with others.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, or mouth. Germs spread that way.

If going out in public, carry hand sanitizer with you to use. The most commonly touched objects in public include touch screens, ATMs, buttons (elevator, vending machines), hand dryers, gas nozzles, shopping carts, etc.
Practice social distancing - Stay at least six feet away from anyone you do not live with.
If you develop flu-like symptoms, call your healthcare provider to determine the next steps for care.
We remind parents not to give aspirin to children with flu symptoms to alleviate fever, as it can put the child at risk for Reyeâ€™s Syndrome, a potentially fatal disease.
